CONTENTdmData.dmGetItemInfo:
{"title":"Special Delivery Cameras","creato":{},"date":{},"dates":{},"publis":{},"contri":{},"subjec":{},"descri":{},"notes":{},"langua":{},"transc":"Special Collections Cameras Detailed information about each camera in the photo from left to right. (far left) Camera: Rainbow Hawkeye Vest Pocket Type: Folding bellows camera Model: None Date: 1930s Manufacturer: Eastman Kodak Format/Film: 127 rollfilm Lens: 4 stops via rotating slide f11 Shutter: T/I Notes: This line came in various colors, including rose and green. Camera: Stereo Graphic Type: 35mm viewfinder stereo camera Model: NA Date: Introduced in 1956 Manufacturer: Graflex Inc., Rochester, New York Format/Film 35mm Lens: Graflex Graflar f4/35mm Shutter: Guillotine Type: shutter between lenses. Speeds of B and 1/50 Notes: As early as 1841, photographers experimented with stereographs, using cameras with two lenses to record images at slightly different angles. When seen in a stereo viewer, the two images are seen as a three-dimensional picture. Interest in stereographic photography has waxed and waned, with periods of popularity in the 1850/60s, the early 1900s, and late 1940s/early 50s. Representing this latest period was the Stereo Graphic, a fixed-focus camera using lenses focused to different distances.

Camera: Mycro Type: Miniature Model: I Date: 1938-40 Manufacturer: Sanwa Co. Ltd., Japan Format/Film: 16mm Lens: Mycro UNA f4.5/20mm Shutter: Behind-the-lens shutter. Speeds of B, 1/24, 1/50, and 1/100sec Notes: This camera is an early example of miniature 16mm format cameras that became popular from the late 1940s through the 60s. The Mycro was produced from 1938 through the 1950s.

1

(far right) Camera: No. 1 Brownie Type: Box Model: NA Date: Introduced in 1901 Manufacturer: Eastman Kodak, Rochester, New York Format/Film: 117 rollfilm Lens: Meniscus Shutter: Eastman rotary. Speeds of T and I Notes: One of several models produced through 1916 based on the original Kodak Brownie box camera first manufactured in 1900. These cameras had a wood reinforced cardboard body and slip-in film back. 117 rollfilm produced six 2 1/4 by 1 in. exposures. The name "Brownie" may have come from popular illustrated poems and stories by Palmer Cox using figures called "brownies."

extension.transcript:
Special Collections Cameras Detailed information about each camera in the photo from left to right. (far left) Camera: Rainbow Hawkeye Vest Pocket Type: Folding bellows camera Model: None Date: 1930s Manufacturer: Eastman Kodak Format/Film: 127 rollfilm Lens: 4 stops via rotating slide f11 Shutter: T/I Notes: This line came in various colors, including rose and green. Camera: Stereo Graphic Type: 35mm viewfinder stereo camera Model: NA Date: Introduced in 1956 Manufacturer: Graflex Inc., Rochester, New York Format/Film 35mm Lens: Graflex Graflar f4/35mm Shutter: Guillotine Type: shutter between lenses. Speeds of B and 1/50 Notes: As early as 1841, photographers experimented with stereographs, using cameras with two lenses to record images at slightly different angles. When seen in a stereo viewer, the two images are seen as a three-dimensional picture. Interest in stereographic photography has waxed and waned, with periods of popularity in the 1850/60s, the early 1900s, and late 1940s/early 50s. Representing this latest period was the Stereo Graphic, a fixed-focus camera using lenses focused to different distances.
Camera: Mycro Type: Miniature Model: I Date: 1938-40 Manufacturer: Sanwa Co. Ltd., Japan Format/Film: 16mm Lens: Mycro UNA f4.5/20mm Shutter: Behind-the-lens shutter. Speeds of B, 1/24, 1/50, and 1/100sec Notes: This camera is an early example of miniature 16mm format cameras that became popular from the late 1940s through the 60s. The Mycro was produced from 1938 through the 1950s.
1
(far right) Camera: No. 1 Brownie Type: Box Model: NA Date: Introduced in 1901 Manufacturer: Eastman Kodak, Rochester, New York Format/Film: 117 rollfilm Lens: Meniscus Shutter: Eastman rotary. Speeds of T and I Notes: One of several models produced through 1916 based on the original Kodak Brownie box camera first manufactured in 1900. These cameras had a wood reinforced cardboard body and slip-in film back. 117 rollfilm produced six 2 1/4 by 1 in. exposures. The name "Brownie" may have come from popular illustrated poems and stories by Palmer Cox using figures called "brownies."
2
